What is
the time?
Flying towards the sunrise (i.e., East), one sees the sun earlier than
+ would have been seen from the point of departure. In other words,
if you fly East you shorten your hours of daylight, and alternatively.
flying West, you are tending to "keep up with" the sun and so
lengthen your daylight hours.
To keep your watches in synchronisation with the daylight, it is
necessary to make the following corrections:
NORTHBOUND

and San

TUR INTEDNATIONAI DATE LINS
The ta ten Date fine was crosted to standardise the com.
mencing and finishing point of a calendar day. Based on the meridian
‡180° fram Greenwich, #is an arbitrary line drawn on a map from
North to South. The effect of the International Date Line is as
follows: When you cross the I.D.L. on the northbound trip you must
the southbound trip the reverse conditions apply and, on crossing
the IDle complate dav is omitted… (For examole, if vou cross the
I.D.L. at 3 p.m. flying westward on what you know as Tuesday, the
day immediately becomes 3 p.m. on Wednesday.)
PRINTED IN AUSTRALIA
Your Instrument Panel
The Story of the
"SOUTHERN CROSS" Route
The "Southern
Cross" route, named
after the first plane to fly the Pacific,
was pioneered in 1928 by Sir Charles
Kinasford Smith. C. P. T. Ulm. H. w
Lyon and J. Warner. On May 31, 1928,
the "Southern Cross" took off trom Oak.
land, California, on the first stage of the
record flight to Brisbane, Australia. 27
hours later, Kingsford Smith made a per-
tect landina at Hawall. As soon as the
"Southern Cross" was refuelled and the crew rested. the second stage
3,128 trackless miles to Fiji, was begun. Despite instrument trouble,
the "Southern Cross" landed at Fiji 34 hours later. The flight from Fift
to Brisbane was made through tropical storms, necessitating much
instrument flying. However, on June 9, after a total of 82 hours 42
minutes in the air, the "Southern Cross," the first aircraft to negotiate
the 7.000 miles across the Pacific. touched down a+ Brisbane.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Flight information packet issued by British Commonwealth Pacific Airlines (BCPA); blue and red folder only; tri-fold format; includes printed information about international date line, "Southern Cross" route, and instrument panels.
